channel.title: Quest tab help

item.title: Quest tab help
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

a primitive datatype wouldn’t show up like that in your text field…

Can you show me the variable in your player/client class?

Read full topic

item.title: Quest tab help
item.dc:creator: @Elegant Elegant
item.description:
@Elegant wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:6, topic:551203”]Nothing you just provided me with helps me…
I told you how to find the variable:

Find where the contract variable is defined in the player class (Or client class) and that will tell you if it’s an object or not.

After you find the variable, if it’s an object, it will be clearly defined as one.
Here’s an example of a primitive datatype being defined.

Different primitive datatypes are:
byte
short
int
long
float
double
char
String
boolean

Here is how an object would be defined:

However, the word “Object” may be substituted with another class name.

Note: defining a variable as “private” is not the only way to do it. You can define it as public, protected, and some others. There are other modifiers you can use on the variable as well.
http://www.tutorialspoint.com/java/java_modifier_types.htm There’s a tutorial talking about different modifiers.
[hr]

If it is an object, then you will need to provide me with the class for it. You can do so by searching the Object name in windows explorer at the root of your project (Like “src”).[/quote]

It is a primitive datatype

Read full topic

item.title: Quest tab help
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Nothing you just provided me with helps me…
I told you how to find the variable:

sk8rdude461:

Find where the contract variable is defined in the player class (Or client class) and that will tell you if it’s an object or not.

After you find the variable, if it’s an object, it will be clearly defined as one.
Here’s an example of a primitive datatype being defined.

Different primitive datatypes are:
byte
short
int
long
float
double
char
String
boolean

Here is how an object would be defined:

However, the word “Object” may be substituted with another class name.

Note: defining a variable as “private” is not the only way to do it. You can define it as public, protected, and some others. There are other modifiers you can use on the variable as well.
http://www.tutorialspoint.com/java/java_modifier_types.htm There’s a tutorial talking about different modifiers.
[hr]

If it is an object, then you will need to provide me with the class for it. You can do so by searching the Object name in windows explorer at the root of your project (Like “src”).

Read full topic

item.title: Quest tab help
item.dc:creator: @Elegant Elegant
item.description:
@Elegant wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:4, topic:551203”]What is the variable “contract”?

Is it an object? Or is it a primitive datatype?

If an object of some form, can I see the class for it?

Find where the contract variable is defined in the player class (Or client class) and that will tell you if it’s an object or not.[/quote]

That I am not sure of, it is for a system called “contracts” that you go to a NPC (http://prntscr.com/6x3rko) to get a contract to kill a boss in a certain amount of time. Here is the interface shop - http://prntscr.com/6x3ru7

Shop - http://prntscr.com/6x3s41

item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

What is the variable “contract”?

Is it an object? Or is it a primitive datatype?

If an object of some form, can I see the class for it?

Find where the contract variable is defined in the player class (Or client class) and that will tell you if it’s an object or not.

item.title: Quest tab help
item.dc:creator: @Elegant Elegant
item.description:
@Elegant wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:2, topic:551203”]Easiest way to figure out which IDs you need to use would be to add a for loop, and send packet 126 to the client.

Something like this:

for(int i = 29169; i < 30000; i++) { getPA().sendFrame126("ID: " + i, i); }
Put that at the end of your code you showed us in the code tags. Compile and run.
Now you should see what ids are what.

Then to add your own, just copy the existing ones, and change your variables, the text, and the id.[/quote]

Okay I got that down, thank you.

Now my last issue is making it pull the actual number - http://prntscr.com/6x3l2c | http://prntscr.com/6x3lno
This is what my issue is - http://prntscr.com/6x3lwm

Thanks for the reply

Read full topic

item.title: Quest tab help
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Easiest way to figure out which IDs you need to use would be to add a for loop, and send packet 126 to the client.

Something like this:

for(int i = 29169; i < 30000; i++) { getPA().sendFrame126("ID: " + i, i); }
Put that at the end of your code you showed us in the code tags. Compile and run.
Now you should see what ids are what.

Then to add your own, just copy the existing ones, and change your variables, the text, and the id.

Read full topic

item.title: Quest tab help
item.dc:creator: @Elegant Elegant
item.description:
@Elegant wrote:

How can I include the “Achievement Points” & “Contract Points” Into the quest tab? Example of my tab here - http://prntscr.com/6x1q24

Here is some of my code to give you a better idea -
http://prntscr.com/6x1qb3
http://prntscr.com/6x1qw1

This is what I can’t figure out (In the red box) - http://prntscr.com/6x1r9z
*Do they all have to continue in order?

here is a snippit of the code ; getPA().sendFrame126("@lre@Donator Credits: @cya@" + Credits + " ", 29169); getPA().sendFrame126("@lre@Vote Points: @cya@" + votingPoints + " ", 29170); getPA().sendFrame126("@lre@Pk Points: @cya@" + pkPoints + " ", 29171); getPA().sendFrame126("@lre@Dung Points: @cya@" + dungPoints + " ", 29172); getPA().sendFrame126("@lre@Player Kills: @cya@" + KC + " ", 29173); getPA().sendFrame126("@lre@Player Deaths: @cya@" + DC + " ", 29174); getPA().sendFrame126("@lre@Exp Lock Status: @cya@" + xpLock + " ", 29175); getPA().sendFrame126( "@lre@Slayer Task: @cya@" + Server.npcHandler.getNpcListName(slayerTask) + " ", 29176); getPA().sendFrame126("@lre@Amount: @cya@" + taskAmount + " ", 29177);

Any help would be great.

Cheers

Read full topic
